posts.name: Alya Nimis-Ibrahim
posts.cooked:
Hello, we are having issues with motors running when they are not supposed to.

The robot code uses 6 motors; 2 motors on each side of the drivetrain, one motor for moving the lift and one motor on our shooter. The drivetrain runs fine with the joysticks in tank drive, and the shooter motor does everything it is supposed to. The lift is controlled by the right and left triggers which move it up and down, respectively. These triggers move the lift motor as they should. However, when the left trigger is pressed, the left drive motor moves in reverse along with the lift motor.

I have tried to write code to stop the drive motors from moving if the lift motors move or if the triggers are pressed, but my attempts have been unsuccessful. I have also switched the direction assigned to each trigger (made the left trigger move the lift up) and the problem still occurred when the left trigger was pressed.

Here is a link to the code on Github: https://github.com/alya222/FRC-2022-Robojacks-ManualClimb.git

**The code includes commented-out attempts to stop the drive motor from running while the lift runs.

And here is a link to a video of the issue with the motors: https://drive.google.com/file/d/11ryqFMq1GwDi1zkt_Hv_EKxeh96U4qr8/view?usp=sharing

Any help would be appreciated, thanks!

Edit: This is an error I am getting: ERROR ÔªøÔªø 1 ÔªøÔªø DifferentialDrive‚Ä¶ Output not updated often enough. Could this be related to the issue I am having?

Also, the drive motors only move with the lift after the drive motors have already been run with the joysticks. Before the drive motors are run, the lift moves up and down with the triggers on its own and the drive motors do not run.

posts.name: Byron Sharman
posts.cooked: Have you double-checked that no motor controllers share a CAN ID?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Have you tried restoring factory defaults on all your motor controllers? I don‚Äôt see anything obviously wrong in the code. However, your liftMoving method will be wrong because it only gets the lift speed at the beginning of the program, not the current lift speed.

posts.name: Alya Nimis-Ibrahim
posts.cooked: Thank you for your reply! I will try restoring factory defaults on the motor controllers when I am able to test on the robot. How would I write the code so that the liftMoving method updates constantly and gets the current lift speed?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Restoring factory defaults is a good guess, motor controllers hold their previously burned settings. It‚Äôs a best practice to restore factory defaults, and burn the settings for Spark Max controllers. Otherwise if your robot browns out you risk having controllers with the wrong settings.

You can do it with the REV Hardware Client, but I recommend doing it in the code so you don‚Äôt have to do it over manually if you swap controllers.

Here‚Äôs an example. You would only want to do this once on robot startup.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
alya:

How would I write the code so that the liftMoving method updates constantly and gets the current lift speed?

You‚Äôre getting the motor speed when you initialize the variable, but then you‚Äôre just referencing the variable. The easiest fix is just to remove the liftSpeed , it‚Äôs not doing anything for you, and reference the motor directly:

Something to consider is that your method is named ‚ÄúliftMoving‚Äù but it doesn‚Äôt actually tell you if the lift is moving , it tells you if the motor is attempting to move the lift. You might want to rethink the name.

Finally, just a bonus comment, you can simplify the method because a conditions result is a boolean .

posts.name: Alya Nimis-Ibrahim
posts.cooked: Thank you for your help! Unfortunately with the changes you suggested involving the conditional command for the drivetrain the code will still not fully deploy onto the robot and displays the message ‚Äúno robot code‚Äù. I also restored the factory settings of each motor controller using the SparkMax Hardware client and this did not fix the issue. Do you have any other ideas on what to do to fix this problem?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Can you include some screenshots of the REV Hardware Client? It would be helpful to see how the drive motors and the climb motor are configured.

I ran your code in the simulator and it not seems to reproduce the problem you‚Äôre having. That leads me to believe it‚Äôs controller configuration or wiring.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
alya:

Unfortunately with the changes you suggested involving the conditional command for the drivetrain the code will still not fully deploy onto the robot and displays the message ‚Äúno robot code‚Äù.

It would be helpful to understand why this happened. Most likely something was not correct and it was throwing an exception and crashing.

Your constructor should look something like this. Can you share the code that failed?

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: I see you guys are competing at Lake Superior this week.  I‚Äôll pass this on to a couple of CSA‚Äôs that will be there, so they can check in on you Thursday morning to help out if you still need it!

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm working through with another team right now when they added a PWMSparkMax in port 4 the motor also a PWMSparkMax in port 1 runs. This was a minor issue so not alot of effort went into trouble shooting.

We tried to move the port 4 motor to port 6 but had no change.

Leaving everything the same but removed the Port 4 motor from code and the port 1 stopped ‚ÄúFollowing‚Äù

did not remove the port 1 motor from code (I want to try this)

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
The first rule of blind* trouble shooting - find somewhere you can monitor that is about halfway down the process, and see if it‚Äôs doing what you expect.  Then do the same with the bad half.  Repeat until you identify the problem.

In this case, you have unexpected motor behavior created by certain U/I (joystick) values.  Add some smart dashboard or other diagnostics which tell you where your robot code THINKS all the joysticks are.  Recreate the problem, and your diagnostics will tell you if you have a U/I/joystick side problem [if the diagnostics don‚Äôt agree with the U/I/joystick positions], or a programming to controller problem [if they do agree].

* Blind trouble shooting is my own term, but basically it means that you don‚Äôt have the hundreds or thousands or millions of hours of experience with a system to be able to target known issues before dealing with unknown and unlikely ones.

posts.name: Alya Nimis-Ibrahim
posts.cooked: I have resolved the issue. The Xbox controller that we were using was faulty and input the left joystick negative value as the lift trigger was pressed. We switched out the controller and the robot is now working correctly. Thank you for all of your suggestions and help!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Sometimes it really is the hardware!
